column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Do Gunpowder Art
#Text=If you ’re tired of drawing and painting , try out the exciting process of creating art with gunpowder and fire !
#Text=Use acrylic paper , canvas , or wood to create a variety of burn styles .
#Text=Make some abstract art by spreading the gunpowder at random , or use brushes to create a detailed , original picture .
#Text=After you get the gunpowder where you want it , grab a fire starter and let the fun part begin ! Light the powder and watch it burn to create your unique artwork .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Gathering Your Supplies
#Text=Buy medium to fine grain gunpowder .
#Text=Go to a local gun shop , outdoor store , or browse online to buy gunpowder .
#Text=Choose small grain powder because it is easier to arrange on the artwork surface .
#Text=Small grain powder creates the effect without creating a large fire .
#Text=There is not a particular brand that you need to buy , just avoid getting coarse grain powder as a beginner .
#Text=Put the gunpowder into a squeeze bottle with a narrow nozzle .
#Text=Look in the grocery store for the type of plastic bottle that you ’d put condiments in .
#Text=Make sure it has is nozzle that allows a small amount of the contents to flow out .
#Text=This is optional , but it works best for beginners .
#Text=This helps you spread the gunpowder precisely on the artwork surface .
#Text=It makes the process easier and allows for greater detail .
#Text=Use paper , canvas , or wood as the base of the artwork .
#Text=Use acrylic coated paper , untreated wood , or standard painting canvas .
#Text=Work outside on a hard , fire-resistant surface if the weather permits .
#Text=If you must work indoors , do it in a garage or shop with a concrete floor and ventilation .
#Text=It ’s best not to do this inside your house or in another place that ’s a fire hazard .
#Text=If it is windy or rainy , you wo n’t be able to keep the gunpowder in the shape you want on the artwork surface .
#Text=Making the Art
#Text=Sprinkle the gunpowder from the bottle onto the base .
#Text=Use the squirt bottle to draw with the gunpowder .
#Text=Make a picture of something specific or make a series of patterns and abstract shapes .
#Text=Be as detailed as you want , depending on what you want to create .
#Text=If the opening of the condiment bottle is too small , cut a bit off to widen it .
#Text=If you do n’t use a bottle with a nozzle , pour the gunpowder out of its container or scoop some out with a spoon and spread it around .
#Text=Use a sponge brush or paint brush to move the gunpowder around .
#Text=If you want to draw something more detailed that sprinkling the gunpowder allows , use paint tools to add details .
#Text=A sponge brush works well because it allows you to push the grains around into detailed shapes .
#Text=Even if you do n’t want to make a specific picture , brushes give you greater ability to shape the gunpowder than sprinkling it gives you .
#Text=Make designs with rocks , boards , or pieces of metal .
#Text=Set objects on top of the gunpowder to affect the explosions when you light it .
#Text=Place objects around the gunpowder so the fire burns the outline of the objects .
#Text=Experiment with different rocks and pieces of wood to create unique designs .
#Text=For example , spread the gunpowder in a thin , even layer across the whole canvas .
#Text=Set a dozen small stones around the canvas on top of the powder to change how it burns .
#Text=Spread the gunpowder , and set a few wrenches on top of it to burn the wrench shapes into the canvas .
#Text=Any object that wo n’t catch fire easily is fair game to add to the artwork .
#Text=Be creative and experiment to find what makes the coolest designs .
#Text=Lighting the Gunpowder Safely
#Text=Wear gloves and safety glasses when you light the gunpowder .
#Text=Since gunpowder is explosive , be sure to wear thick gloves made of fabric , not rubber or plastic .
#Text=Also wear a good pair of safety glasses to protect your eyes in case something sparks .
#Text=Use a fuse so you have time to move back .
#Text=If you are worried about the gunpowder catching fire too quickly , place a fuse at the edge of the artwork .
#Text=Use a foot ( .3 m ) or two ( .6 m ) of 2.5 mm ( .09 in ) artillery fuse .
#Text=Lay it so it touches the gunpowder and extends off of the base .
#Text=It ’s okay to light the gunpowder directly , but you may not feel comfortable doing this .
#Text=A fuse also adds a neat effect when it burns the artwork .
#Text=Light the fuse or the gunpowder near an edge or corner of the artwork .
#Text=If you use fuse , simply light the end that extends off of the artwork .
#Text=If you choose to light the gunpowder directly , light it at a corner or edge of the design .
#Text=This is the best way to allow the fire to spread across the artwork .
#Text=Stand at a distance while the gunpowder burns .
#Text=As soon as you light the gunpowder or fuse , step back three feet or more from the artwork .
#Text=In case a bit of the gunpowder pops , you do n’t want to be close .
#Text=You also want to avoid breathing the smoke directly into your nose and mouth .
#Text=Keep a fire extinguisher or water on hand in case the fire spreads .
#Text=Even though this is a controlled setting , it is still fire and requires you to take precautions .
#Text=Watch the artwork carefully , and act immediately if you feel that it is getting out of hand .
#Text=Remove debris from the artwork after the fire goes out .
#Text=When all of the gunpowder is burned up , it will most likely leave some particles .
#Text=Shake the excess into the trash , scrape it off , or use a vacuum wand to clean it off .
#Text=If you like the way it looks and it ’s burned on , leave it as part of the artwork .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Children should not do this type of artwork without close adult supervision .
#Text=Clear anything flammable far away from the spot where you ’re working .
